Cultural Zionism was one of several ideological positions within the Zionist movement whose political wing was represented in the World Zionist Organization by the Democratic Fraction, formed at the Zionist Congress of 1901 by Ahad Ha’am and Martin Buber. Adherents of cultural Zionism focused on cultural work in the Diaspora rather than strictly on the political goal of forming a state.
